title: Best font for Bible pocket size
content:
Hi everyone

Any sugestions to what would be the best font to use in a Bible. The format will be pocket size so the size of the font will have to be small, probably between 6 and 7. Traditionally bibles have two columns, but i might use one since its quite a small format.

So far have experimented with

Warnock Pro (I like its optical font)

Frutiger (a fresh and youth feel to it)

Kepler

Any more suggestions...

Thanks

Sorry, if i have post this in the wrong place, I am new to this forum...
author: alpha

comments.content:
Biblon! It would be awesome to use it for a bible.

—K

Good one John.  
What about Paperback?

hhp

" [Parable](http://web.archive.org/web/20110220224304/http:/www.hiberniatype.com/Parable/parable.html) is a versatile serifed face for serious typography. It is optimized for print in small text sizes (between 6 and 10 point). Yet, some of its features prove to be interesting characteristics at larger sizes also: such as the ‘dug-out’ shoulder junctions of h, n, m etc, and the thin midriff of lowercase g (designed to avoid filling in at small sizes).

Parable has low stroke contrast, making it robust and adaptable to many circumstances, and it has a proportionally large x-height for optimum legibility in text. The italic provides a strong, cursive contrast to the roman, and attention has been paid to giving it a distinct identity, with quite different forms for certain characters of punctuation (see margin). With small capitals, and bold & extra bold weights, Parable is equipped for all kinds of complex typography."

"Best" without price caveats might be [Lexicon,](http://web.archive.org/web/20110220224304/http:/www.teff.nl/fonts/lexicon/lexicon.html) which I think was designed for dictionaries, hence good for pocket bibles. I get a religious feeling reading it. But that may just be how gorgeous/functional it is. ;)

I hate to be all self-promotional and junk, but [Beorcana Micro](http://web.archive.org/web/20110220224304/http:/www.beorcana.com/specs4.html) might be sympathetic. It certainly works very small.

\> I get a religious feeling reading it.

Must be a ductal faith thing.

hhp

Lexicon shows how artful design can be. Something that works so well shouldn't look so good, right? But it does. And there's a lot of very smart design in it. It's an example of design and art blended elegantly; pushing something utilitarian beyond design.
How interesting-- Lexicon has the biblical bonus of having an oddly Hebraic looking question mark. Nice, but it's not what I expect of a question mark.

**Any idea when DTL Sheldon is available? Could be an interesting choice.**

ƒ

I think the Le Monde Journal would be a good typeface for what you're looking for. It had been design especially for small size:  
 [http://www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/LeMondeJournal](http://web.archive.org/web/20110220224304/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/LeMondeJournal "http://www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/LeMondeJournal")

Fredrik, what’s up with the strong? Should everything you say be strongly emphasized so it stands out from the not so good stuff everybody else writes? Just wondering.

I second Paperback.

Probably so. It just stops my reading every time. You wouldn’t set a book in bold, would you?  
Anyway, you may be as bold as you wish.

Maybe he -rightly- prefers 2-pixel stems?  
(Although I guess anything can happen in OSX.)

hhp

haha, i like this suggestion

\>Lexicon  
I love it

I would love to see it in that context

My suggestions so far  
Weidemann, Stempel Garamond (maybe a bit too wide for this, but can be very readable -and elegant- when set good in smaller sizes)

I figured since you'll be printing a book with really small type including lots of numbers, Bell Centennial was made for just that sort of thing.
